articles.headline: S.E.C. Approves Rule on C.E.O. Pay Ratio
articles.snippet: Requiring companies to compare the chief executive’s compensation with that of employees could further stoke a debate over income inequality.
articles.abstract: Requiring companies to compare the chief executive’s compensation with that of employees could further stoke a debate over income inequality.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of General Electric raked in a $37.3 million pay package last year, a large sum by any standard.

articles.headline: Liquefied Natural Gas Makes Qatar an Energy Giant
articles.snippet: A rich natural gas field and a fleet of ships has turned Qatar, once a poor nation of fishers and pearl divers, into a major player in the global energy trade.
articles.abstract: A rich natural gas field and a fleet of ships has turned Qatar, once a poor nation of fishers and pearl divers, into a major player in the global energy trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAS LAFFAN, Qatar — The temperature hovered around 100 degrees on the jetty here, where a set of pipes were connected to a giant red-hulled ship. But the moisture in the air froze on the pipes and flaked off, creating snowlike flurries on the early summer evening.

articles.headline: It’s Either Iran Nuclear Deal or ‘Some Form of War,’ Obama Warns
articles.snippet: President Obama portrayed the coming vote in Congress on the deal as the most consequential foreign policy decision for lawmakers since the vote to authorize the invasion of Iraq.
articles.abstract: President Obama portrayed the coming vote in Congress on the deal as the most consequential foreign policy decision for lawmakers since the vote to authorize the invasion of Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama took on critics of the nuclear deal between Iran and six world powers in an aggressive speech on Wednesday, saying they were the same people who created the “drumbeat of war” and played on public fears to push the United States into the Iraq war more than a decade ago.

articles.headline: Disney, Time Warner and Other Media Shares Fall as Investors Worry About TV’s Future
articles.snippet: Shares in Comcast, Time Warner, 21st Century Fox, CBS, Viacom, Discovery and AMC Networks all were down, with some plunging by as much as 12 percent in midday trading.
articles.abstract: Shares in Comcast, Time Warner, 21st Century Fox, CBS, Viacom, Discovery and AMC Networks all were down, with some plunging by as much as 12 percent in midday trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: If ESPN is having trouble, is the rest of television burnt toast?
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Texas ID Law Called Breach of Voting Rights Act
articles.snippet: The court ruling centers on a state requirement that would-be voters produce some specific forms of government-issued photo identification.
articles.abstract: The court ruling centers on a state requirement that would-be voters produce some specific forms of government-issued photo identification.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel ruled Wednesday that a strict voter identification law in Texas discriminated against blacks and Hispanics and violated the Voting Rights Act of 1965 — a decision that election experts called an important step toward defining the reach of the landmark law.

articles.headline: Spain Says Banker’s Seized Picasso Will Head Back Home
articles.snippet: Customs officials confiscated the painting, valued at nearly $30 million, after its owner’s yacht left Spain for French waters.
articles.abstract: Customs officials confiscated the painting, valued at nearly $30 million, after its owner’s yacht left Spain for French waters.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — To the Spanish authorities, Picasso’s 1906 “Head of a Young Woman” is a unique painting, the only example in Spain from a pivotal period in the artist’s life. Because of that status, the courts labeled it a “national treasure” that should not be sold outside the country.

articles.headline: Jon Stewart, Sarcastic Critic of Politics and Media, Is Signing Off
articles.snippet: Mr. Stewart attracted a generation of viewers ready to embrace an outlier whose exaggerations, in their view, carried more truth than conventional newscasts.
articles.abstract: Mr. Stewart attracted a generation of viewers ready to embrace an outlier whose exaggerations, in their view, carried more truth than conventional newscasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday night 10 presidential candidates will spill onto a stage in Cleveland, and the already crowded Republican primary race will begin in earnest with the first day of debates, live on Fox News.

articles.headline: The Tale of an Anxious Economic Recovery, Told by a Revived Textile Mill
articles.snippet: After closing during the recession, the 150-year-old Faribault Woolen Mill in Minnesota is back in business. But its workers are not resting easy.
articles.abstract: After closing during the recession, the 150-year-old Faribault Woolen Mill in Minnesota is back in business. But its workers are not resting easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Founded 150 years ago, the Faribault Woolen Mill in Minnesota survived the Great War and the Great Depression, not to mention World War II. But it almost did not make it through the Great Recession.

articles.headline: Among the States, Self-Driving Cars Have Ignited a Gold Rush
articles.snippet: The auto industry will spend billions developing the technology, and many states are being careful not to pass laws that would scare those dollars away.
articles.abstract: The auto industry will spend billions developing the technology, and many states are being careful not to pass laws that would scare those dollars away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whether it is fuel savings, safer commutes or freed-up time behind the wheel, motorists have many reasons to embrace self-driving cars.
